array.string: Day of the Tiles in Grenoble, first revolt against the king.
The royal treasury is declared empty.
Riots in Paris by workers. Twenty-five workers were killed in battles with police.
The Assembly proclaims freedom of speech.
First issue of Jean Paul Marat's newspaper, L'Ami du peuple, proposingl social revolution.
Election of a new municipal assembly in Paris, with three hundred members.
Louis XVI abruptly dismisses Necker. Parisians respond looting the monastery of the Lazaristes.
Storming of the Bastille. A large armed crowd besieges the Bastille.
The King reinstates Necker as finance minister.
After an orderly march, a crowd of women invade the Palace.
The Assembly decrees that Protestants are eligible to hold public office; Jews are still excluded.
The Assembly forbids the taking of religious vows.
The Assembly votes to abolish the privileges and feudal rights of the nobility.
The Assembly proclaims freedom of religious opinions.
The Assembly adopts the Declaration of the Rights of Man and of the Citizen.
The Assembly abolishes the requirement that army officers be members of the nobility.
Pope Pius VI condemns the Declaration of the Rights of Man in a secret consistory.
Clergymen are required to take an oath of allegiance to the government.
Joseph-Ignace Guillotin, a doctor, proposes a new and more humane form of public execution.
Marat publishes a fierce attack on finance minister Necker.
Paris municipal police try to arrest Marat, he escapes to London.
Necker, the finance minister, is dismissed.
Louis XVI writes to King Frederick William II of Prussia asking for a military intervention.
The Assembly orders that the silver objects owned by the Church be sold to fund the government.
Marat returns to Paris and resumes publication of L'Ami du people.
The Assembly abolishes the titles, orders, and other privileges of the hereditary nobility.
Marat publishes a demand for the execution of five to six hundred aristocrats.
The Assembly orders the transfers of the ashes of Voltaire to the Panthéon.
The Assembly forbids priests to wear ecclesiastical costumes outside churches.
Emperor Leopold II calls on the royal houses of Europe to come to the aid of Louis XVI.
The Assembly decrees that the tricolor will replace the fleur-de-lys as emblem of France.
Mesdames, the daughters of Louis XV and aunts of Louis XVI, depart France for exile.
Diplomatic relations broken between France and the Vatican.
The Assembly granted freedom to slaves in Haiti.
The Assembly closes the Sorbonne, a center of conservative theology.
The war begins. The army of Rochambeau invades the Austrian Netherlands.
Louis XVI formally accepts the new Constitution.
The Assembly declares that all men living in France, regardless of color, are free.
Claude Pastoret, a monarchist, is elected President of National Legislative Assembly
The Assembly orders the raising of an army of twenty thousand volunteers.
Louis XVI vetoes the laws on the deportation of priests.
Decree by the Assembly allows working-class citizens to join the National Guard.
The Assembly votes to summon a mass army of volunteers to defend the borders of France,
Austria and Prussia sign a military convention to invade France and defend the monarchy.
La Marseillaise composed by Joseph Rouget de Lisle, is sung for the first time in Strasbourg.
Lafayette tries unsuccessfully to persuade his army to march on Paris to rescue the royal family.
First judgement by the Revolutionary Tribunal and execution by the guillotine of a royalist.
The government requisitions all church objects made of gold or silver.
The Assembly orders the deportation of priests who have not signed the oath to the government.
Storming of the Tuileries Palace. The King and his family take refuge in the Legislative Assembly.
Royal family imprisoned in the Temple.
Last session of Assembly votes a new law permitting civil marriage and divorce.
The French army under Dumouriez invades the Austrian Netherlands . They occupy Brussels.
The Convention claims the right to intervene in any country to"free the people".
The Assembly abolishes the religious teaching orders and those running hospitals.
Lafayette leaves his army and goes into exile.
Creation of the Louvre Museum displaying art taken from royal collections.
Breaking of diplomatic relations between England and France.
Armed royalist uprising against the Convention begins in Brittany.
The Convention declares war against Spain.
The Convention proclaims the abolition of royalty and the First French Republic.
Robespierre, leader of the Jacobins , demands that the King be put to death.
Opening of the trial of Louis XVI before the Convention.
First session of the Revolutionary Tribunal.
At the Jacobin Club, Robespierre and Marat call for an insurrection against the Convention.
An armed crowd of sans-culottes storms the Convention and demands that it disband.
The Convention declares Louis XVI guilty of conspiracy by a vote of 707 to zero.
Louis XVI is beheaded at 10:22 on Place de la Révolution.
The Convention declares war against England and the Dutch Republic.
Robespierre elected to the Committee of Public Safety.
Marie-Antoinette is transferred from the Temple to the Conciergerie.
Soldiers of the Convention capture Marseille.
Marat is brought before the Revolutionary Tribunal, and is acquitted of all charges.
Ratification of new Constitution by the National Convention.
Charlotte Corday assassinates Jean-Paul Marat in his bath.
The Convention forbids religious instruction by clerics.
The Revolutionary Tribunal sentences the 21 Girondins deputies to death.
On Robespierre's orders, supporters of Danton are arrested.
The Convention adopts the principles of the metric system.
Robespierre is elected the president of the Convention.
Convention adopts a new Law, permitting rapid trial of anyone opposing the Revolution.
The Convention votes to abolish slavery in French colonies.
Robespierre tells the Convention that "All the factions must perish from the same blow."
Hébert and leaders of the Cordeliers are condemned to death and guillotined.
The Convention orders that Marie-Antoinette be tried by the Revolutionary Tribunal.
The Army of the Convention defeats the Austrian Army at the Battle of Wattignies.
The Cathedral of Notre Dame is re-dedicated as a Temple of Reason.
Danton, Camille Desmoulins and their supporters arrested.
Robespierre creates a new Bureau of Police attached to the Committee of Public Safety.
Execution of Madame Élisabeth, the sister of Louis XVI.
The Paris Commune orders the closing of all churches and places of worship in Paris.
Napoléon Bonaparte lead an operation forcing the withdraw of British from Toulon
Napoleon Bonaparte is promoted to general for his role in driving the British from Toulon,
French forces under Jourdan defeat the Austrians at the Battle of Fleurus.
Robespierre speaks at the Jacobin Club, denouncing a conspiracy against him.
Robespierre attends a meeting with the Committees of Public Safety and the dispute seems settled.
Trial of Danton: He uses the occasion to ridicule and insult his opponents.
Danton and Desmoulins are convicted and guillotined the same day.
The chemist Antoine Lavoisier is tried and guillotined.
After an orderly march, a crowd of women invade the Palace.
The Assembly decrees that Protestants are eligible to hold public office; Jews are still excluded.
The Assembly forbids the taking of religious vows.
Robespierre is unanimously elected president of the Convention.
The Convention votes the arrest of Robespierre, of his younger brother Augustin Robespierre.
Robespierre is guillotined Place de La Concorde.
The Assembly abolishes the requirement that army officers be members of the nobility.
Pope Pius VI condemns the Declaration of the Rights of Man in a secret consistory.
Clergymen are required to take an oath of allegiance to the government.
Execution of Fouquier-Tinville, the public prosecutor during the Terror.
Election of new Directory and end of Convention.
Bonaparte’s coup d’etat removes Directory and establishes himself as First Consul.
French forces under Jourdan defeat the Austrians at the Battle of Fleurus.
The Assembly forbids the taking of religious vows.
The French army under Dumouriez invades the Austrian Netherlands . They occupy Brussels.
